--- In neat@yahoogroups.com, Jeff Clune <jclune@...> wrote:
>
> Thanks Ken.=
 I am currently running experiments with different ratios of
> addNodeProb =
to DemolishNodeProb to see what effect that has both on node
> number and f=
itness.
> 
> A few questions/replies below:
> 
> > One issue with bloat tha=
t is easy to overlook is that the population
> > contains a range of networ=
k sizes and therefore the maximum size of a
> > network in the population i=
s not necessarily a measure of "bloat"
> > because other species may contai=
n significantly smaller networks.
> > What you probably want to check is th=
at a healthy range is being
> > maintained rather than simply trying to pre=
vent anything from
getting big.
> 
> I was referring to the number of nodes=
 in the generation champion.
The task
> is pretty simple (it does not requi=
re hidden nodes), yet they ramp
up about
> a hidden node every 2.5 generati=
ons, which seems overly fast to me.
Does it
> to you?  
> 

That does sound=
 a bit fast.  Maybe the mutation rate could just be
lowered.  However, if i=
t's the champion itself that's bloating, you
need to be careful because the=
re are two possible cases.  

One is that adding a node actually made fitne=
ss increase.  In that
case, it is not "bloat" at all because it actually is=
 helping.  Then
there is no problem.

On the other hand, if you are getting=
 neutral additions to structure
to the champion itself, one question I have=
 is what happened to the
previous champion who didn't have the structure?  =
If you have elitism,
there should be a clone of the prior champion in the c=
urrent
generation, and that clone would not have any additional structure.
=

So the question is how is the champion getting bigger?

If a champion has =
an offspring that has the same fitness as the
champion but also a new node,=
 then you do have bloat.  And if this
happens every 2.5 generations, I'd te=
nd to suggest lowering the node
addition rate.

> > In general, there is go=
od reason to grow networks if fitness is not
> > going up because the algor=
ithm has no way of knowing what is necessary
> > to improve.  It might need=
 more structure, or it might simply need to
> > find a better set of weight=
s.  Therefore, it is sensible for it to try
> > both: If you are stagnating=
, keep growing at one end of the spectrum,
> > but also don't lose your lit=
tle guys in case they turn out sufficient.
> >  In other words, a stagnant =
population should gradually grow in its
> > range of sizes, not putting all=
 its eggs in one basket.
> 
> Interesting point. I guess I should be lookin=
g at min number of
nodes in the
> population, and see if that is growing fa=
st as well.
> 
> > For populations that are not stagnant, it makes sense fo=
r them to
> > display less growth in general, because they are succeeding i=
n their
> > current weight space.  I'd guess your more recent experiment is=

> > undergoing periods of stagnation, which would explain why you see more=

> > growth.
> 
> Are you saying that NEAT has a built-in mechanism such th=
at the node
number
> will increase during times of fitness stagnation, and =
that the rate of
> hidden node growth is less when fitness is improving? Wh=
at
mechanisms bring
> this about?
>  

I don't mean to suggest that it has =
a special built-in mechanism to
know if it is stagnating or not.  But I am =
claiming that it is a kind
of emergent phenomenon that happens because of s=
tagnation.  If you are
stagnating, then adding structure tends to produce i=
ndividuals that
are as fit (before fitness sharing) as any other (because n=
othing is
improving).  Therefore, there is a more condusive environment to =
many
different structures surviving (since the fitness competition is less
=
fierce).  On the other hand, if a particular species is charging ahead
simp=
ly by optimizing weights, then new species that add new structure
will not =
take up as much of the population because they won't be
optimizing as fast.=


ken
